Disease # 6944 - Lymphomatoid papulosis

Other Names: LyP

Categories: Blood Diseases Rare Cancers Skin Diseases

This disease is grouped under:

Summary: Lymphomatoid papulosis (LyP) is a non-contagious, chronic skin condition characterized by the eruption of recurring, self-healing bumps (lesions) on the skin.[14862] The lesions typically begin small and then become larger, and they may bleed or ulcerate before becoming scaly and crusty.[14862][14863] They often develop a red-brown color.[14862] Symptoms associated with lesions may include itching and/or pain, which may be debilitating.[14862][14863] The frequency of eruptions varies over time and from person to person. Lesions may be very persistent, or they may go away for long periods of time before coming back.[14862] They may occur anywhere on the body, but they typically develop on the trunk, arms, and legs, and may develop on the hands, face, and genitalia.[14863][14864] They generally go away on their own over a period of weeks to months (usually between 3 and 8 weeks), with or without scarring.[14863] LyP is not contagious.[14862][14863] The cause of LyP is not known, but there is no evidence that it is hereditary.[14862] Stress is often reported to trigger eruptions of lesions.[14862] The duration of the condition varies from person to person and may last months, years or decades.[14863]

A diagnosis of LyP requires evaluating the symptoms and having a skin biopsy for various types of laboratory tests. While LyP usually is not classified as a cancer (although there has been some debate), it has characteristics of lymphoma under the microscope, and people with LyP have a life-long increased risk of developing lymphoma such as mycosis fungoides, PC-ALCL, or Hodgkin lymphoma.[14862][14863][14864] In 5 to 20 percent of people with LyP, the condition is either preceded by lymphoma, associated with lymphoma, or followed by lymphoma.[14863][14864] When LyP is diagnosed it is important to rule out these cancers, and for this reason, various blood tests or imaging studies may also be recommended.[14863]

Treatment for LyP may speed up the healing of existing lesions or prevent new lesions from forming, but it does not change the overall course or duration of the condition.[14863] People with only a few lesions or with no major symptoms or cosmetic concerns may opt to forego treatment. If treatment is desired, topical corticosteroids are an option. Options for people with extensive skin lesions or debilitating symptoms may include topical steroids, phototherapy, oral or topical retinoids, methotrexate, or other medications (alone or in combination).[14862][14863] Tetracycline is typically used if ulcerated lesions become infected.[14865] In most people with LyP-associated lymphomas, treatment of the lymphoma will also clear the LyP.[14862]

The long-term outlook (prognosis) in more than 90% of people with LyP is positive, as it usually does not affect overall health.[14862] People with LyP who do not develop cancer have a normal life expectancy. While there is a substantial risk to develop lymphoma, the reported mortality rates from associated lymphomas are low.[14863]

  • The Monarch Initiative brings together data about this condition from humans and other species to help physicians and biomedical researchers. Monarch’s tools are designed to make it easier to compare the signs and symptoms (phenotypes) of different diseases and discover common features. This initiative is a collaboration between several academic institutions across the world and is funded by the National Institutes of Health. Visit the website to explore the biology of this condition.
